page.title: 08THE OLD RAILWAY,WITHERNSEA
page.content: The railway from Hull to Withernsea was opened in 1854,having taken a year to build,and was closed in 1964 as part of the Beeching axe.The local council has recently dismantled the platform and demolished the row of workers' cottages.The station building is now somewhat derelict and used by the market which is held on a Thursday,Saturday and Sunday.The area which formerly contained the turntable is now used for open-air stalls.The Sunday market is particularly popular and open all the year,drawing visitors from a wide area and often causing the town to be totally jam-packed. In the meantime all evidence of the railway is disappearing and an example of 19th Century industrial archaeology is being lost.Street names survive,notably Railway Crescent and Bannister St. named after the founder.
